body:
You are right - It probably *would* make more sense if the ONNX spec said use `INT_MAX` for postive steps and `INT_MIN` for negative steps. This makes logical sense. The spec is ambiguous when it says - "For slicing to the end of a dimension with unknown size, it is recommended to pass in INT_MAX". 
Numpy supports a single "special index" - `None`, which works for positive and negative stepping. I just treated `INT_MAX` to be the `None` equivalent of Numpy while implementing. 

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/aa041026e362f0728232b4aeec3a23a48ed3d70f/onnxruntime/core/providers/cpu/tensor/slice.cc#L188

But we do need to be consistent with the shape inference logic as well. 

I think we can fix this easily - by clarifying the spec in ONNX and then remove the special casing in ONNX Runtime. The `else` equivalent of the same `if` block does the clamping which will handle the `INT_MAX` and `INT_MIN` special indexing.

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/aa041026e362f0728232b4aeec3a23a48ed3d70f/onnxruntime/core/providers/cpu/tensor/slice.cc#L199
Agreed, and the shape inference logic in ONNX needs to be fixed for the reverse cases.

Well, if the spec is clarified to make `INT_MIN` the "special end of the dimension index" while reverse stepping, I think the shape inference logic in ONNX can remain as such. The shape inferencing logic already does clamping in case the `ends` are out of bounds and this clamping logic will handle `INT_MAX` while forward stepping and `INT_MIN` while negative stepping. In case `INT_MAX` is provided while negative stepping the shape should be {0} as what it is doing right now (if my understanding is correct)...

Please try the repro to change the Slice reverse test cases to use initializer. You'll find out ONNX inference generates output shape of [0] for start=-1, end=INT_MAX, step=-1, because it clamps end to len, so start-end = 0...

The test passes now because of [relaxed shape check](https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/commit/3cda9f717bb780e2af9a0057c8d90db06869927c). You'll still notice warnings when running the test:

2019-10-31 00:28:49.398331981 [W:onnxruntime:Default, graph.cc:73 MergeShapeInfo] Error merging shape info for output. 'output' source:{0} target:{4}. Falling back to lenient merge.

Actually I don't see the warnings. I even stepped through the test in VS to see if it fails the shape inference and falls back into the relaxed shape check code, and it doesn't and it merges the source and target shapes which seem to have the same values. Maybe, we can sync via a call tomorrow.
Just found that existing tests use INT_MAX for end when step < 0, and that's why I still saw the error. Yes you are right that if INT_MIN is used for reverse in the test case, it would be OK.

Hi @KeDengMS ,

I created an issue in ONNX for tracking this - https://github.com/onnx/onnx/issues/2433. Since the spec is currently ambiguous, I don't think we have anything to change in ORT at this moment. So closing this out. Please re-open if you have further comments. Thanks!
